The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. These results provide insights into the origin of the Myxozoa and the extreme reduction in gene content and genome size that is characteristic of parasitic cnidarians. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will increase the variability of global crop yields. This study quantifies the magnitude of this increase and its consequences for global food security. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in most of the world’s major maize-producing countries. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the causes of biodiversity and the consequences of human land use. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because species-level identification of food plants is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, and many are anticipating difficulties accessing the CARES Act. We also find that businesses that received loans from the CARES Act were more likely to survive the crisis than businesses that did not.

Plastic debris is a major environmental problem in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study is of great importance to understand the global distribution of floating plastic debris and its fate in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is a major unsolved problem in astrophysics. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. These ages are consistent with the formation of the solar system. The ability to reproduce is the most fundamental of all biological functions. In this study, we examine the effect of different forms of maternal provisioning on reproductive output. We find that all forms of provisioning, including domestication and allonursing, increase reproductive output. The greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process, and patients die within a few years after disease onset. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. VX-765 prevented motor deficits in the model and reduced the load of truncated α-syn in the striatum. VX-765 showed neuroprotective effects by preserving tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. In conclusion, our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling vascular tone, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network that is highly efficient in the transmission of information. The network is also highly dynamic and able to rapidly respond to changes in the environment. These findings reveal the design principles of the endothelium and provide a foundation for understanding the function of the endothelium in cardiovascular physiology.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis. In the United States, the pandemic has been characterized by a patchwork of policies and public behavior, and the data have been similarly complex. We present a data infrastructure that provides a common framework for tracking the pandemic, and a common data format for sharing and reusing the data. The infrastructure is open source and available to the public.

Anxiety is a major risk factor for social disorders, yet the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We identify the nucleus accumbens as a key brain region involved in this process. In particular, we show that the energy metabolism of the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and that this is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures with multiple material phases that can be digitally synthesized and seamlessly assembled into composite structures. The synthesized structures can precisely realize arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The proposed strategy can be extended to design structures with complex behaviors and functionalities. The proposed strategy can be applied to design mechanical devices with specific behaviors for various applications.

The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a key regulator of oxygen delivery to tissues. The Hb system is also a target of the let-7 microRNA (miRNA) pathway. Here we investigated the role of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the heterochronic regulation of Hb expression in human erythroid tissues. We found that IGF2BP1 is down-regulated in fetal versus adult erythroid tissues. In vitro overexpression of IGF2BP1 in erythroid cells resulted in a reversal of the adult Hb expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This was achieved by increased gamma-globin expression and decreased beta-globin expression. The fetal-like Hb expression was mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of Hb expression in humans. Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy and succumb to the disease. Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the mechanisms of resistance to therapy are complex and poorly understood. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, we show that SREBP1-mediated ferroptosis resistance can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to evaluate the influence of this policy on biodiversity. Our results show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral ecosystems but failed to reverse the decline of older forests. The NWFP also failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our findings also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management in policy evaluation. This is the first study to evaluate the influence of the NWFP on bird populations. Our findings provide a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of a policy on biodiversity. This is important because policy evaluation is often difficult and costly. Our findings can be used to inform policy evaluation in other areas.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. We used a computational approach to predict the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics toward the ribosome. We then synthesized the top-ranked compounds and tested them in vitro for their inhibitory activity. We also evaluated the compounds in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our approach can be used to design new antibiotics against other targets. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results show that the proposed architecture is a promising alternative to popular existing architectures.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime has important effects on sleep. Reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation. However, its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. This was not fatal, but led to organ-specific autoantibodies. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is a key regulator of both self-tolerance and autoimmunity. This study provides a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. It also provides a model for studying the role of CTLA-4 in different diseases. Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species. Our analyses resolved the evolutionary history of beetles and revealed that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. These novel genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles, resulting in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that PCWDEs enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists and cultural anthropologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our findings have implications for the evolution of technology and the emergence of culture. They also have implications for the design of experiments that investigate the role of culture in the evolution of technology.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest and densest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is a mystery because its formation mechanism is unknown. We demonstrate that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is a metastable phase. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase of iron, which is the stable phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. It also provides a new perspective on the formation of other solid bodies in the solar system.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is illegal, it is widely available, and its use is increasing. The drug is also associated with a range of negative consequences, including impaired cognition, violence, and motor vehicle accidents. The present study provides evidence that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is reduced in marijuana abusers. The reduced reactivity might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language prediction also predict the brain’s responses to sentences in humans. This suggests that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms. We also find that model architecture appears to substantially contribute to neural fit. These results provide computationally explicit evidence that predictive processing shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also provide a promising approach for understanding the brain’s language machinery in health and disease.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is not clear whether this success is due to the inherent properties of DL or to the fact that it is a black box. We show that the latter is the case. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities. However, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the psychology of exponential growth. The most prominent study in this field is a classic experiment published 45 years ago. Despite its many flaws, it is still often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We discuss the study’s critical design flaws and show that they led to the study’s authors overestimating the extent to which people are unable to understand exponential growth.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a human pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to infect the peripheral nervous system, and is therefore likely to be neuropathogenic. Phylogenetic analyses suggest that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA than M. leprae, and a Bayesian dating analysis suggests that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 13.9 Mya. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. The evolution of entanglement is a key ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. However, the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems is a long-standing open problem. We show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the interacting system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors. In contrast, the only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development is described in this paper. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but robustly grows at the permissive temperature. The vaccine induces high levels of spike-specific antibodies in hamsters, which are protective against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. The vaccine is easy to manufacture and can be stored at 2–8 °C, which is a major advantage over other vaccines. These features make the vaccine suitable for mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for studying the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known story, but the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. We show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is more complex than brain size. We also show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is associated with cognitive ability.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the target of many existing drugs. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. Severing is a key process in many cellular processes, including cell motility and cytokinesis. However, how ADF severes filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on ADF binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon ADF binding. We find that this ADF-induced torque dramatically enhances severing. A simple model, which faithfully recapitulates our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in response to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on health.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is also revealed by the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island. The results suggest that the settlement of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the human history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the human history of other islands.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This is a major finding, because it suggests that people’s emotions are not private, but are instead influenced by the emotions of others. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is a critical component of the protein synthesis machinery. The ribosome, the protein component of the machinery, reads mRNA sequences to direct translation of the genetic code. We have shown that the presence of a single modification in mRNA can alter the rate of translation. We found that the presence of a modification in mRNA can alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the ribosome can encounter modifications in mRNA and that the modification can alter the rate of translation.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better physical and mental health, less pain, greater physical activity, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust over a 4-y period and are not driven by factors such as depressive symptoms or prosperity. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. This study provides evidence for the importance of a sense of worthwhile living in the context of aging. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body size is a defining characteristic of the evolution of life on land. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body size in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. The evolution of larger body size in aquatic mammals is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlated with significantly higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) at 37 °C. Temperature-dependent IFN induction in response to rhinovirus was dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). Stimulation of primary airway cells with the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C led to greater IFN induction at 37 °C relative to 33 °C at early time points poststimulation and to a sustained increase in the induction of ISGs at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. The opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients. It is able to cause severe lung damage by producing a wide range of virulence factors. The mechanisms that allow this pathogen to adapt to the lung environment and cause disease are not well understood. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its surface-associated type IV pili to detect surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This is a unique mechanism that allows bacteria to sense the environment on short timescales and to adapt their behavior accordingly. This finding has important implications for the understanding of the mechanisms that allow bacteria to adapt to the lung environment and cause disease. It also provides a potential target for the development of new anti-infective strategies.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the consequences of this development for the quality of surface water are not well understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the quality of surface water is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides should be reduced and that current environmental regulations should be strengthened.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including white-tailed deer, and can be transmitted between these species. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer in the United States. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our findings suggest that the virus is likely circulating in wildlife and that the risk of spillback into human populations is high. This underscores the need for continued vigilance and increased surveillance efforts. Our study also highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of wildlife in the pandemic. This is critical to developing effective strategies for mitigating its impact. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern. This paper examines the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder with no known cure. The disease is characterized by chronic inflammation, which is most often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to amyloid-β (Aβ) plaque deposits and cell death. However, this reaction is observed in transgenic animal models devoid of such pathologies. We propose that this plaque-independent inflammatory reaction originates from neurons burdened with increasing levels of soluble and oligomeric Aβ, which are known to be the most toxic amyloid species within the brain. Laser microdissection of neurons extracted from preplaque amyloid precursor protein (APP) transgenic rats revealed that neurons produce a variety of potent immune factors, both at the transcript and protein levels. Neuron-derived cytokines correlated with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. We also demonstrate within disease-vulnerable regions of the human brain that a neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede insoluble Aβ plaque and tau tangle formation. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present evidence from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant as early as the fourth century B.C.E. and that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry predates this date by at least a century.

The folding of large proteins is a major unsolved problem in molecular biology. We studied the folding of the maltose binding protein, a 370-residue protein, by monitoring the folding process at high structural resolution. We found that the folding process is highly heterogeneous, with a fast collapse into a polyglobular state and a slower formation of a distinct folding intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory pathway on the way to the native state. The intermediate is composed of segments that are distant in the sequence but adjacent in the native protein. The intermediate is the first step on the folding pathway, and it is the site of three destabilizing mutations. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results also suggest that the folding of large proteins is more complex than previously thought. (Read more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to RNA caps, which are required for their biological activity. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap of Np4-capped RNAs in Escherichia coli is also capable of removing capped RNAs in a stress-dependent manner. This enzyme, which is normally inactive in the absence of disulfide stress, is able to recognize capped 5′ termini by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which this enzyme recognizes capped 5′ termini and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for developing new arginine-based therapies for other immune-mediated diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, where systems evolve in a self-sustaining manner. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, which is a signature of criticality. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and has a low fracture strain, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly under thermal strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are also relevant for the design of diamond-based devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of plant immune peptides in defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis of antifungal activity of plant immune peptides is not well understood. Here, we report the crystal structure of a 36-residue NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula. This structure was largely disordered and dynamic. However, it exhibited potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The antifungal activity was associated with the binding to bioactive phosphoinositides and the disruption of the fungal cell wall. The structure of the peptide and its mode of action provide a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this class of peptides. This work also illustrates the potential of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. We combined proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Read more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Platelet function is altered in von Willebrand disease (VWD), a common disorder. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of VWD mutations, explaining pathophysiology. Conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This work provides a mechanism for how VWF binding to platelets is regulated. It also provides a mechanism for how mutations in VWF cause bleeding disorders. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that interact with humans, has been difficult to study. This study analyzes over 4,000 human metagenomic datasets, finding over 45,000 unique virus taxa. The study also analyzes over 2,200 case-control studies, finding that viruses are strongly associated with disease. These results will help researchers study the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is because of the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties. This instrument can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. We conducted continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing using this instrument. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. However, this finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the ACI research.

The Earth’s surface temperature has been inferred from the isotopic compositions of marine cherts to have decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Here, we present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes reconstructed from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean. This finding is consistent with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. We conclude that the isotopic paleotemperature record is robust and that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean. This is important for understanding the origin and early evolution of life on Earth. The

Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in most K+ channels occurs upon sustained membrane depolarization or channel opening and then recovers during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or channel closure. Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the erythrocyte, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a major advance in our understanding of the parasite’s invasion strategy and could lead to the development of new strategies to combat the disease. This article is protected by copyright. Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks under mechanical stress. Can diamond be completely metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, so that its electronic bandgap fully vanishes? We show that diamond can be metallized reversibly in a wide range of strain space. We also explore phonon-instability conditions that promote phase transition to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our work is expected to advance the understanding of the fundamental physics of diamond and its applications. The machine-learning-based approach can be extended to other materials. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. This may be particularly important in the context of climate change

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by successively merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain implements this merge operation, however, remains unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate how brain activity varies with each successive word in a sentence. We found that each additional word or phrase contributed a similar amount of additional brain activity, suggesting that the brain applies the same merge operation to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Formal model comparison indicated that the model of multiword phrase construction provided a better fit than probability-based models at most sites in superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices. Activity in those regions was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for development and homeostasis. Axin is a key component of the pathway. We show here that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), and that this circuit is necessary for the development of overeating. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is not mediated by the dopamine system. These results provide a characterization of a circuit that may contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited. Thus, nitrogen-fixing bacteria are essential for sustainable agriculture. However, the use of these bacteria is limited by the need for a close association with the plant. Here, we show that the plant can control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria, allowing them to fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This could lead to a sustainable and efficient nitrogen supply for agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and a critical ecosystem for climate regulation. Despite the importance of the Amazon, it is one of the most difficult forests to monitor. We study a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation in the region. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the difficulty of measuring deforestation in the Amazon. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize the source of sound. The acoustic sensors of animals are constrained by the size of the organism, and the acoustic sensors of spiders are limited by the size of their bodies. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear by outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is more sensitive to acoustic waves than the acoustic sensors of all previously known animals. The spider can remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave, such as those emitted by prey or predators. The spider can also increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than its body, and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of sensory function in animals.

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing pollution particles liberates 0.73 °C, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. This strategy can be applied to other subunit vaccines. The engineered RBD can be expressed in large quantities in bacteria, and the VLPs can be produced in mammalian cells. The role of the ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) in development and disease is well established. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs (DrALKs) are activated by secreted ALKALs. We further show that the ALKALs are involved in zebrafish pigment pattern formation and neural crest development. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings are important for understanding the role of ALK family RTKs in development and disease. They also provide a model system for studying the role of ALK family RTKs in human development and disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of plague as a major human pathogen is a well-documented event in history, but the details of its early evolution remain poorly understood. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age. Our results show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic was already present in Europe and the Near East by 5,000 y BP. This lineage rapidly spread across Eurasia, with a significant increase in the number of genomes recovered from the Bronze Age. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its adaptation to its new host. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a key question in climate change mitigation. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage in a long-term field experiment on a Midwestern Mollisol. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and manure addition. We also show that the magnitude of the SOC response to these practices is highly dependent on the region of the world and the type of soil. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to increase SOC storage in agricultural landscapes. This is important because grasslands are the most extensive land use on the planet and are a key component of climate-smart agriculture. Our results also highlight the importance of soil microbial traits in the SOC response to soil health management practices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the most likely spillover candidates, which can be used to inform research and public health interventions. We validated the framework using a large dataset of viruses from wildlife. The SpillOver platform is a living database that can be used to continuously improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We anticipate that the SpillOver platform will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. The framework can be applied to other viruses and pathogens to prioritize research and control efforts.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. The emergence of new pathogens and the spread of existing ones are a constant threat. The rapid detection of pathogens is critical to the containment of outbreaks. We used a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. Ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used in other resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate the spread of infectious diseases. This article is protected by copyright. The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The process is highly processive and requires the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) to maintain the stability of the polymerase holoenzyme. We developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the polymerase holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results suggest that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more similar to the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme than previously thought. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human cell. The human cell has evolved to maintain a high rate of DNA replication in the absence of PCNA. Our results suggest that the human cell has evolved a more dynamic pol δ holoenzyme to maintain the high rate of DNA replication.

The origin of life is a central problem in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be evolved to have catalytic activity, and in this paper, we show that RNA molecules can also have polymerase activity. We used in vitro evolution to improve the polymerase activity of an RNA molecule, and we demonstrated that the improved polymerase can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes of cities over time and to study the physical dynamics of cities. It can also be used to study the physical changes of cities in the context of other social and economic changes.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 have been analyzed. The pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality. The results provide a new therapeutic strategy for severe COVID-19.

The maintenance of sufficient but nontoxic pools of metal micronutrients is a fundamental process in all organisms. In fungi, the role of iron-binding compounds in the homeostasis of this essential micronutrient has been well established. Here we demonstrate that, in Aspergillus fumigatus, copper-binding compounds derived from the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) impact cellular copper content and have significant antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xanthocillin BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the evolution of metal homeostasis in eukaryotes and the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of microbial interactions. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, in a mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is explained by the cogenetic origin of the tridymite and other crystalline minerals. The tridymite is a detrital phase, possibly from silicic volcanism in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The amorphous silica is a mixture of precipitated silica, diagenesis products, and/or a residue of acidic leaching. The post-lithification mixed-cation salts and oxides are precipitates and/or their diagenesis products. The presence of tridymite in a mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of SiO2 that is not stable at present-day Earth conditions. The presence of tridymite in a mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is also significant because it is a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of SiO2 that is not stable at present-day Earth conditions.

Frost events are a major cause of crop and forest losses, but the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly related to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees. We also show that the frequency of late-spring frosts is increasing in Europe and Asia, and that this trend will likely continue in North America. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. We found that Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. Moreover, Th17 cells could directly transition to Th1-like cells and were required for the development of colitis in a Stat4-dependent manner. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. They also suggest that targeting Th17 cells may be a useful therapeutic strategy in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, and the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This method will be useful for ALS research and drug development. The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. We now demonstrate that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of its vector to more efficiently colonize the tick. We show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota by perturbing the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier. IAFGP also alters the composition of the gut microbiota by increasing the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vector and may be relevant to the transmission of other infectious agents. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian tail is a key step in the origin of flight. The study of the early evolution of the avian tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of flight. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal can be used to avoid predators, attract mates, or blend in with the environment. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein binds biliverdin, a molecule that is normally found in the blood. We describe this protein and show that it is most similar to human anti-proteases.

The role of N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modification of messenger RNA (mRNA) in regulating pluripotency has been described, but the physiological signals that determine the balance between methylation and demethylation have not been described. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which demethylated NANOG mRNA at an m6A residue in the 3′-UTR. Increased NANOG mRNA and protein expression, and the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype, were induced by hypoxia in an HIF- and ALKBH5-dependent manner.
