The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization that preceded the extinction is punctuated by a sharp (3‰) negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will also be useful in evaluating the potential for a repeat of the Permian-Triassic extinction

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for neutralizing antibodies. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the two most common forms of the virus, which differ in the presence or absence of the D614G mutation. We show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion with the host cell membrane.

We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We also show that our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales can be used to predict and rationalize the chemical phenomena observed under pressure. This work is a first step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the net effect is uncertain because of the complex interactions between climate, fire, and human demography. We show that human demography can have a strong influence on fire activity, with implications for the carbon cycle. We find that reductions in human demography have suppressed global fire activity throughout the 20th century, but recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and reduce warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate. However, with some risk of more extreme fires regionally. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand the role of human demography in future fire regimes. This is important for the management of fire-dependent ecosystems and the mitigation of climate change.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel fashion. We show that the glycan is provided just before dusk, when the symbiotic organ is at its most vulnerable, and that the glycan is catabolized in the symbiotic organ, which is required for the acidification of the organ that enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. This study provides a mechanism by which the host can regulate the activities of the symbiont. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We first identify a set of vectors that provide a sparse representation of an embedding space. We then infer the latent patterns that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Instead, we suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium into Europe, which were delayed by 15 ± 1 y by climate-driven changes in the rodent population. The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting a wide range of species of sea stars. The disease is caused by a virus that has spread to many species of sea stars. We show that the virus is the most likely cause of the disease and that it is transmitted by the virus-infected sea stars. We also show that the virus has been present in sea stars for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of new targets for therapy is of great importance. Here, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling is effective in suppressing the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The IL1RAP-targeting antibody used in this study is currently in clinical trials. Thus, the results presented here provide a proof of principle for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based therapy of AML. This study also provides a rationale for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based therapy of other diseases in which IL1RAP is expressed on disease-initiating cells. (Read more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the human history of Madagascar. They also have implications for the human history of Africa

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We propose a method to convert the original categorical data into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting probabilistic variable is robust across different crops, exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed method can be applied to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a powerful tool to study the evolution of life on Earth. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. This model can be applied to other lineages of organisms that have lost photosynthesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is relevant to policymakers and decision makers in South Africa and other countries in SSA. It is also relevant to the global climate community, as it highlights the importance of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of multiyear droughts. This article is protected by copyright. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known quasicrystal was discovered in 1984, but the conditions under which it was formed are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown icosahedral quasicrystal in red trinitite, the first anthropogenic quasicrystal and the oldest known material on Earth to be created by human hands. The discovery of this quasicrystal provides a unique link between the past and the present, and it demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed under conditions that are not hostile to life.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. A diiron cyclase is required in a betaproteobacterium, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease. ASK1 signaling in microglia activated astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. The probability of drought years has increased because of the combination of warm conditions and dry precipitation. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that the reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the causal paths that lead to autism. This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that result in bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that the inhibition of endocytosis in vulnerable neurons may be a useful therapeutic strategy. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus metabolic targeting is a promising strategy for cancer therapy. Here we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic vulnerability of colon cancer. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We show that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. Thus, defective glycine import is a metabolic vulnerability of DLBCL. These results suggest that targeting formate metabolism is a promising strategy for DLBCL therapy. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by the aggregation of mutant proteins, which are highly aggregation-prone and form intracellular inclusion bodies. Here, we show that the inclusion bodies in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and suggests that the disease is caused by a progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The origin of the flowering plants is a major event in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants that colonized the surface of the water. The study of the aquatic flowering plants Montsechia and Ceratophyllum, described here, raises questions about the very early diversification of the flowering plants.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Read more)

Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. We estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y to be 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This is in agreement with the average rate of sea level rise over the same period. We find that the rate of sea level rise is increasing, which is consistent with the findings of the IPCC AR5.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been steeper for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the mortality rate is high. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a drug that is used to treat Ebola, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the composition of their microbiota. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel fashion. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn is required for the acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which in turn is required for the luminescence of the symbionts. This glycan-catabolizing activity is established only in the mature symbiosis, suggesting that the glycan may be a key determinant of the stability of the mutualism. DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe pneumonia, and its origin from bats and transmission to humans are well established. However, the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection are not fully understood. Here, we show that sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV spike (S) proteins is required for efficient infection of human lung-derived cells. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. These findings suggest that the first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These results also provide a rationale for developing vaccines and antiviral therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this system. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a large impact on sales. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in many settings.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We applied quantitative proteomics to a panel of oncogenes to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion. We found that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward understanding how the surfaceome is remodeled in cancer cells. The surfaceome is a promising target for drug discovery and biomarker discovery. The surfaceome is also a promising target for immunotherapy.

In response to the coronavirus pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to more than 50 million confirmed cases and over 1.2 million deaths worldwide. The virus has a complex set of proteins that are involved in its replication and immune evasion. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. We show that the structure is similar to the SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a protein, but with unique dimerization interfaces that are likely to be involved in immune evasion and immune suppression. Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanism for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema in hypoxia. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema in hypoxia. The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are “strong” and “significant.” Unfortunately, the word “significant” is not well defined. It is used in different ways in different contexts. It is used to mean “statistically significant” (which means that the association is unlikely to have occurred by chance). It is also used to mean “practically significant” (which means that the effect is large). It is also used to mean “important” (which means that the association should be studied further). We describe a new way of thinking about significance that is more appropriate for the world of big data.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells. The ETV2-induced ECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETV2-induced ECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETV2-induced ECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. These findings also provide a promising therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders and the generation of vascular plexus to regenerated organs. This article is protected by copyright. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we show that the augmentor ligands of Alk and Ltk are essential for zebrafish iridophore patterning. We also demonstrate that the augmentor ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the adult eye and body coloration in the adult zebrafish. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the physiological function of Alk and Ltk and their ligands. It also provides a model system for studying the physiological function of orphan RTKs in general. Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in regulating insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global STING knockout (STING−/−) and β-cell–specific STING knockout (STING-βKO) mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, the human and avian influenza viruses. The avian influenza viruses are divided into three subtypes, A/chicken/Australia/3001/97 (H5N1), A/chicken/Vietnam/1/2004 (H5N1), and A/chicken/Hong Kong/2440/05 (H7N9). These viruses are highly pathogenic for humans and can cause severe disease. The molecular details of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular details of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. They also provide a basis for the development of new antiviral strategies. The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key athero-protective factor. However, the underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study also provides a rationale for the development of athero-protective strategies based on the disturbed flow. These strategies may be useful for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a major threat to human life and property. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely played a role in the increase in wildfire activity. However, the role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occurred in areas with higher fuel moisture. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in increasing fire risk and should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic well-being of neighborhoods. This may be useful for policymakers and urban planners.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropod pests remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, the single-celled algae that live inside the coral host. We provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of altered nutrient cycling in the breakdown of the symbiosis and discuss the implications of our findings for our understanding of the functioning of endosymbiotic relationships in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky, leading to systemic infections. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can alter the composition of the microbiome, which in turn can promote tumor growth. We also show that the tumor-induced activation of JNK signaling leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and barrier dysfunction. Our results identify a mechanism by which the tumor microenvironment can alter the composition of the microbiome, leading to a vicious cycle of tumor growth and dysbiosis. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain intestinal barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the treatment of intestinal tumors. They also suggest that the microbiome may be a promising target for cancer prevention. This article is protected by copyright. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the main treatment for breast cancer, but resistance to chemotherapy is a major problem. Here we show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice, which is associated with the expression of genes involved in breast cancer stemness. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can eradicate breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. The timing of the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is still a matter of debate. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series at the start of deglaciation is consistent with a role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the climate system. This finding provides a plausible explanation for the start of accelerated deglaciation and the associated climate changes, and it has implications for the timing of the end of the last ice age.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food and income for hundreds of millions of people, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions of low food security. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in rivers where potential impacts on biodiversity are highest. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is restricted to a specific neuron type. We also show that this form of regeneration is a powerful platform for discovering genes that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. These studies provide a unique model for studying the molecular control of intrinsic regeneration in the adult nervous system. They also suggest that the ability to regenerate after injury is a conserved feature of the adult nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. In humans, recombination is a key process in the formation of the human genome. However, the distribution of recombination across the human genome is not well understood. Here, we present a detailed map of recombination across the genome of a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no detectable recombination. This variation is similar to that seen in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we used metabolic PET to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks (RSNs) in healthy and disease populations. In healthy subjects, the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN). In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. Significant reductions in the default mode network were already present in Alzheimer’s disease, progressing over time. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, significant reductions appeared later, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. This approach can be used to identify and validate reproducible RSNs, and to assess their functional significance. This study provides a proof of principle for the use of metabolic imaging in the study of the resting brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for efficient translation and stability of the mRNA. The 5′ cap structure is also found on tRNA and rRNA. Here we show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We propose that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We examined whether epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me differences during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) persist at certain loci associated with glycemia for several years during the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Future studies are needed to determine the mechanisms of action of DNA-me in this context. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high rate of relapse. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The tomato is a model system for studying fruit ripening and the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds. The tomato clade includes several species that produce distinct mixtures of volatile compounds, which are important for the overall flavor of the fruit. The underlying biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are not known. Using an introgression population, we identified a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the volatile compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. It also provides a model for understanding the biosynthesis of other nitrogenous volatiles in other fruit species. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. As temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result is driven by two processes: (i) more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions, and (ii) the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increases at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that biodiversity loss will exacerbate the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning if species’ thermal tolerance traits are not considered. This is important for understanding the impacts of biodiversity loss and climate change on ecosystem functioning. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It encodes the local environment in the form of a map of space, which is represented by a combination of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. How these cell types are organized in MEC is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves, but weakly coupled to other cell types. These data suggest that grid cells might have a distinct network from other cell types. Our findings also suggest that the MEC space map is not a simple sum of the maps of other cell types. This is important for understanding the function of MEC in navigation. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of the host and the parasite in a host–parasite interaction. This study illustrates how a parasite can use flowering as a means to synchronize its own flowering with that of its host. This is an important aspect of the evolution of parasites, as it allows the parasite to time its reproduction exactly with that of its host.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The precise nature of the pathophysiology of the disease is unknown, however, and the mechanisms by which dopamine systems are altered in health and disease are not well understood. Here, we show that the dopamine-containing nigral system is organized into specialized subsystems that are affected in Parkinson’s disease. These subsystems are composed of striosome–dendron bouquets, which are highly specialized integrative units that are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine-containing nigral system. The bouquet organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system is a general feature of the brain and may be relevant to the function of other systems. The bouquet organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system may also be a target for therapeutic intervention.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for heart rate regulation and are characterized by their unique electrophysiological properties. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia that is associated with an increased risk of stroke. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and is required for their automaticity. We show that STIM1 regulates Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs by modulating store-operated Ca2+ entry and L-type Ca2+ current. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in SANCs and provide insights into the mechanisms underlying SAN dysfunction. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for atrial fibrillation. (Read more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well documented, its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses, including insect herbivory, have been well documented. In addition, the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway plays a crucial role in mediating antiherbivore defense responses in plants. However, potential interactions between JA and Si in response to insect attack have not been examined directly. To explore the role JA may play in Si-enhanced resistance, we silenced the expression of allene oxide synthase (OsAOS; active in JA biosynthesis) and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1 (OsCOI1; active in JA perception) genes in transgenic rice plants via RNAi and examined resulting changes in Si accumulation and defense responses against caterpillar Cnaphalocrocis medinalis (rice leaffolder, LF) infestation. Our results suggest a strong interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores involving priming of JA-mediated defense responses by Si and the promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results provide insights into the underlying mechanisms of Si-enhanced resistance against insect herbivory. This article is protected by

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results demonstrate a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in lipid metabolism and in the regulation of the lipidome. They also have implications for understanding the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in the regulation of ether lipid metabolism in other cell types. Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based biotechnologies. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based biotechnologies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Eutrophication is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, and it is driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that small tributaries exhibit nutrient loads that are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone, increasing the likelihood of coastal eutrophication. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This article is protected by copyright. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation in dynamical systems, which is a well-known phenomenon in the study of stability. We also find that the dynamics of the system are sensitive to the details of the environment, and that the system can exhibit a variety of behaviors depending on the environment. These results have implications for the study of complex systems in general, and for the study of chemical systems in particular.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, which in turn can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and show that the same key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis can be used to explain the same parameters in a mouse model. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same parameters that are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition can be used to predict the susceptibility of the brain to overt EEG paroxysms when these parameters are changed. This could lead to the development of biomarkers and therapeutic targets. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid climate change, and the consequences of such changes are unknown. To understand the Earth system response to abrupt climate change, we need to know how the system responded to gradual climate change. Here, we present a study of a 300-million-year-old abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was accompanied by a global warming and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an increase in organic matter burial and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results can help us understand the Earth system response to rapid climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for palm oil, but rather a tool that can be used in conjunction with other policies to reduce deforestation. We also show that certification is not a substitute for other policies that reduce deforestation, such as the moratorium on new concessions. Our results are important for the palm oil industry and for policy makers considering the use of certification as a tool to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Read more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual can have a major impact on its fitness. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with a single locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent, and the sex of the offspring is determined by the sex of the parent. In species with multiple loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent, but the sex of the parent is determined by the sex of the parent. This can lead to a variety of outcomes, including the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles. We show that the multiple loci of polygenic sex determination can lead to modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the retina is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-induced photoproducts of vitamin A. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings indicate that Fe is a key factor in the photodegradation of bisretinoids in the retina. Understanding the role of Fe in the photodegradation of bisretinoids may be important for the development of strategies to protect the retina from the damaging effects of light

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and their evolution is a key factor in the evolution of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end. We show that siphonophores, a group of predators that are highly specialized on a single prey type, can evolve into generalists. This is possible because the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological innovations. Our findings help understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a remarkable adaptation that has allowed us to dominate the planet. The evolution of the human hand is a key to understanding our origins and evolution. However, the evolution of the human hand is poorly understood because of a lack of fossil evidence from before 1.8 My ago. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand, was present in a 1.42-Myr-old fossil from Kenya. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human behavior. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus cancer cells must meet the increased demand for energy and biosynthetic precursors. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human cytosolic and mitochondrial serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT). We show that dual SHMT inhibition blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibition in the treatment of cancer, and suggests that targeting the glycine import pathway is a promising strategy for the treatment of lymphoma. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that deforestation can have negative effects on people’s diets. This is important because people’s diets are often not adequate in terms of micronutrients, and this can lead to micronutrient deficiencies. The results have important implications for policy makers because forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is based on the use of farm machinery, which has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
